article.title: Introduction to &product;
article.para:
The &product; project is a rewrite of the original GeneX 1.4 project which was initially conceived at National Center for Genome Resources (NCGR)
as a proprietary software project. Along with two other projects, &product; has emerged from this earliest version as a direct result of diverging requirements and a need for a practical and functional system. &product; is open source and freely available at the SourceForge web site.

The evolution of &product; continues to be driven by the need to get the greatest use of gene expression data. Developers at the University of Virginia, through modification and innovation, have created a secure, web based relational database management system that allows users to load, archive, manage and analyze gene expression data.

&product; includes:
A convenient user interface based on the workflow of biomedical microarray research. Investigators login via a web browser to enter a variety of general and MIAME required information pertaining to their array studies, experimental conditions, samples, and hybridizations.
The array center has been supplied with a number of online processing tools which allow them to track and bill array orders, create reports, and manage work load. Special center support is included so the array center can adjust their array order approval and billing practices according to each center's individual requirements.
A web tool that allows each user to post his array data for public access. Public data can be viewed and downloaded from the main &product; web site without a user account. It can also be analyzed via the &product; set of analysis tools by simply creating a public access account. In addition, personal data can be analyzed once uploaded to the &product; system.
An innovative Analysis Tree interface that can interactively incorporate different analytical tools into a unified analysis tree. &product; is a database combined with an integrated toolset to enable researchers to analyze their data, and in some circumstances to make a comparative reference to public data. Text delimited data sets can be uploaded, regardless of technology, to be analyzed.
The current analysis tools include:
up-to-date statistical methods for discovering differential expression patterns in microarray data: t-test, SAM, permutation test, and LPE (Local Pooled Error) test, especially the last recommended for small-sample (less than six replicated arrays per condition) microarray data analysis,
statistical and functional filtering,
annotation tool which can provide many different types of annotation and functional information, and
hierarchical clustering tool which provides both cluster-image-map and direct links to National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) genome information sites for each microarray data set analyzed.

article.title: History of &product;
article.para:
The &product; project is a rewrite of the original GeneX project which was initially conceived at National Center for Genome Resources (NCGR)
. The original GeneX is largely considered to be a prototype and has been leveraged in the development of three separate projects:
&product;
GeneX 2
GeneX-Lite
All three projects have emerged from this early version as a direct result of diverging requirements and a need for a practical and functional system. &product; is composed of a relational database, a web-based user interface and an analysis system.

Although &product; is historically related to the original GeneX project, it has diverged considerably and has an entirely new code base. The original name of &product; was GeneX-Va since it was created at the University of Virginia with the involvement of the Virginia Bioinformatics Consortium (VBC).

A small team at the University of Virginia rewrote Genex 1.4 and released Genex Va 1.5 in October of 2002. Since that time many upgrades have been made and there are frequent new releases. In 2004 GeneX-Va was renamed to &product; to more accurately reflect its framework and to avoid any confusion among project names. The product is installed and used regularly by the UVa array center and UVa researchers. Development on the project is on-going as we continue to add new functionality and improve on the user interface.

article.title: Home Page
article.para: The home page provides an introduction to the product and provides a starting point for all &product; activity. Users can login via the login interface on the left side bar. If they are already logged in, there is an "Already logged in" link to take them directory to the appropriate set of GUI tools for their user type. Non-users may make use of several publicly available functions including downloading and viewing public gene data, requesting a &product; account on that installation, reviewing &product; documentation, or downloading &product; source.

Depending on the installation, there may be several other items viewable. Logos of supported special centers may be displayed on the left hand side of the page. Additionally, there may be special descriptive or news items of interest to users of that installation on the page. An example of a news item would be a &product; training session being provided. These items are configured by the Administrator for each installation via the Configure &product; link.

sect1.title: View Public Data
sect1.para: If a researcher chooses to publish their experiment data on &product;, it will be available via the "View Public Data" link. Each box on this page represents one study. Currently, there are no special navigational/search controls for this page, but that is planned for future development.

Each study is delimited in a separate box. The first items displayed are the study name, a short description, and the name of the PI. The first link provides MIAME information about the study in either text or html format. Following that are the chip data files associated with the study. Files can be downloaded by clicking on the link.

Occasionally, if a study has just be published, data may be unavailable. If this is the case, a message to that effect will be returned. This likely means that the public data administrator is verifying the publication information, and the files will be posted shortly. If the files are not available after several days, contact the &product; administrator for that installation.

sect1.title: Request An Account
sect1.para: This link allows non-users to request an account on a specific &product; installation. For security reasons, not all installations support all account types. If not all account types are supported there may be a link to a companion installation that supports the missing types.

To request an account, first select the desired account type, then click 'Next'. Then fill out the fields for account generation. &mandatory; Although an email address is not required for some user types, it is highly recommended that you provide one as &product; sends emails to communicate details regarding account creation and analysis results.

An email containing account details is send immediately if the request is for a public user account. If the request is for a different account type, the response email may take a couple days, as it is necessary for the administrator to verify validity of the account request.

sect1.title: &product; Documentation
sect1.para: The &product; Documentation links provide access to all product documentation. The documentation is divided into sections based on user type. Each section contains overview articles that provide general discussion of specific tasks that type of user may wish to perform, a detailed discussion of each of the GUI options available to that type of user, and an FAQ section. If you have questions that are not addressed by the documentation or have noticed inaccuracies in the documentation, please email &product; developers so that the concern can be answered and documentation modified accordingly.

article.sect1: &product; Downloads Currently, &product; downloads are available from the SourceForge. The downloads link from &product; home page takes the user directly to the relevant page.
